articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
A while back on CSS-Tricks, we shared several ways to draw hearts, and the response was dreamy. Now, to show my love, I wanted to do something personal, something crafty, something with a mild amount of effort.
Handwriting an SVG Heart, With Our Hearts originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Handwriting an SVG Heart, With Our Hearts

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Adamâ€™s such a mad scientist with CSS. Heâ€™s been putting together a series of â€œnotebooksâ€ that make it easy for him to demo code. Heâ€™s got one for gradient text, one for a comparison slider, another for accordionsâ€¦
Scroll Driven Animations Notebook originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Scroll Driven Animations Notebook

articles.author: Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez
articles.description:
Weâ€™ve been able to get the length of the viewport in CSS sinceâ€¦Â checks notesâ€¦Â 2013! Surprisingly, that was more than a decade ago. Getting the viewport width is as easy these days as easy as writingÂ 100vw, but â€¦
Typecasting and Viewport Transitions in CSS WithÂ tan(atan2()) originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Typecasting and Viewport Transitions in CSS WithÂ tan(atan2())

articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
I enjoy organizing code and find cascade layers a fantastic way to organize code explicitly as the cascade looks at it. The neat part is, that as much as it helps with "top-level" organization, cascade layers can be nested, which allows us to author more precise styles based on the cascade and inheritance.
Organizing Design System Component Patterns With CSS Cascade Layers originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Organizing Design System Component Patterns With CSS Cascade Layers

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Stationery Pad is a handy way to nix a step in your workflow if you regularly use document templates on your Mac. The long-standing Finder feature essentially tells a fileâ€™s parent application to open a copy of it by default, ensuring that the original file remains unedited.
Make Any File a Template Using This Hidden macOS Tool originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Make Any File a Template Using This Hidden macOS Tool

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
A little gem from Kevin Powell's "HTML & CSS Tip of the Week" website, reminding us that using container queries opens up container query units for sizing things based on the size of the queried container.
Container query units: cqi and cqb originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Container query units: cqi and cqb

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
The steps for how I took the Baseline Status web component and made it into a WordPress block that can be used on any page of post.
Baseline Status in a WordPress Block originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Baseline Status in a WordPress Block

articles.author: Ryan Trimble
articles.description:
Are partials the only thing keeping you writing CSS in Sass? With a little configuration, it's possible to compile partial CSS files without a Sass dependency. Ryan Trimble has the details.
Compiling CSS With Vite and Lightning CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Compiling CSS With Vite and Lightning CSS

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Did you see the release notes for Chrome 133? It's currently in beta, but the Chrome team has been publishing a slew of new articles with pretty incredible demos that are tough to ignore. I figured I'd round those up in one place.
Chrome 133 Goodies originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Chrome 133 Goodies

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
When using View Transitions youâ€™ll notice the page becomes unresponsive to clicks while a View Transition is running. [â€¦] This happens because of theÂ ::view-transitionÂ pseudo element â€“ the one that contains all animated snapshots â€“ gets overlayed on top 
â€¦
Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running

articles.author: Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez
articles.description:
All of the things that the CSS Working Group would change if they had a time-traveling Delorean to go back and do things over.
The Mistakes of CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: The Mistakes of CSS

articles.author: Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez
articles.description:
The @view-transition at-rule has two descriptions. One is the commonly used navigation descriptor. The second is types, the lesser-known of the two, and one that probably envies how much attentionÂ navigationÂ gets. But read on to learn why we need types and how it opens up new possibilities for custom view transitions when navigating between pages.
What on Earth is theÂ `types`Â Descriptor in View Transitions? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: What on Earth is theÂ `types`Â Descriptor in View Transitions?

articles.author: Andy Clarke
articles.description:
After 20 years since Andy Clarke first published his book about Multi-Column Layout in CSS, he's back to encourage a fresh look at CSS columns for enhanced readability and design flexibility.
Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Revisiting CSS Multi-Column Layout

articles.author: Preethi
articles.description:
When it comes to positioning elements on a page, including text, there are many ways to go about it in CSS â€” the literal position property with corresponding inset-* properties, translate, margin, anchor() (limited browser support at the moment), and so forth. The offset property is another one that belongs in that list.
Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I was reading through Juanâ€™s recent Almanac entry for the @counter-style at-rule and Iâ€™ll be darned if he didnâ€™t uncover and unpack some extremely interesting things that we can do to style lists, notably the list marker. Youâ€™re probably already â€¦
Some Things You Might Not Know About Custom Counter Styles originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Some Things You Might Not Know About Custom Counter Styles

articles.author: cloudboyu
articles.description:
cloudboyu: 
Generate and display full-screen color backgrounds for your presentations, photography, and creative projects.
website address: https://screencolors.org
Detailed introduction:
ScreenColors is a simple, free tool for displaying solid colors on your screen. With ScreenColors, you can easily assess whether your monitor is free of defects. You can also explore different colors such as black, red, green and blue, or create your own using the color picker. It's a simple and effective way to test and enhance your screen!
The system default settings for screen colors are:
White Screen
Black Screen
Blue Screen
Green Screen
Purple Screen
Red Screen
Yellow Screen
Orange Screen
Pink Screen
You can also customize the colors.
Key Features
Multiple Color Options:Choose from our curated selection of colors or create your own custom screen.
Download in Any Size:Export your color screens in various resolutions up to 8K quality.
Custom Color Picker:Use RGB or HEX values to create exactly the color you need.
